2007",Different from the Respondent State,Legal immigrant (foreign born person who has been legally admitted to the country concerned and is not seeking protection),Yes,"48, 55, 76","The applicants complained that their eviction and the demolition of their home after decades of tolerance on the part of the authorities towards the construction of houses in the Cañada Real Galiana had amounted to a violation of their right to respect for their private and family life. The public authorities had not taken account to minimum safeguards during the procedures. The measure did not pursue a legitimate aim and was not necessary in a democratic society. Neither did the applicants have the proportionality of the measure assessed. The applicants also complained of the manner in which the eviction had been carried out (at night, without prior notice and with a significant police presence). Lastly, the balance between the interests at stake should lead to the conclusion that the applicants’ eviction and the demolition of their home had not been necessary or urgent, and caused irreparable damage – particularly to the minor children – on the basis that the public authorities had not provided credible and permanent alternative housing.",44-48,Yes,53-55,Yes,N/A,Yes,N/A,Yes,N/A,"The Court reiterates that it does not matter that the applicants have constructed the house unlawfully, as the concept of “home” within the meaning of Article 8 is not limited to those premises which are lawfully occupied or which have been lawfully established. “Home” is an autonomous concept which does not depend on classification under domestic law. As the lawfulness of the interference was not disputed, the Court further states that an interference will be considered “necessary in a democratic society” for a legitimate aim if it answers a “pressing social need” and, in particular, if it is proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued. While it is for the national authorities to make the initial assessment of necessity, the final evaluation as to whether the reasons cited for the interference are relevant and sufficient remains subject to review by the Court for conformity with the requirements of the Convention. The Court observes further that the unlawful occupation of public land in the Cañada Real Galiana had been de facto tolerated by the authorities for decades, however, there have been multiple incidences where the applicant was told to stop the construction of the house. Further, the applicants were able to challenge the first demolition order, but did not do so, however, after the first demolition of his home the first applicant started to rebuilt his home. The Spanish Courts provided for a sufficient degree of procedural measures and judicial protection. The Court does not find a violation of Article 8.",53-81,No damages,N/A,N/A,N/A,N/A
